Gamma rays and x-rays come from lightning strikes, electrical arcing, arc welding. Gamma ray bursts are just evidence of electrical arcing between objects in space. All so called black holes in space are actually gamma or x-ray sources. So since black holes are actually mathematically impossible, it is likely that these bursts are electrical arcing between stars being electrically stressed, possible busted apart at the galactic cores. Hannes Alfven has already explained these polar jets and predicted synchrotron radiation from them.
    The first known spark plug was invented on February 2, 1839 by Edmond Berger.  All we have to do is get past this black hole nonsense and figure out how we can create gamma ray bursts here on Earth and extrapolate that into space, and we will figure out how they can be generated.
  So gamma ray bursts are not from objects rotating at 66000 rpm, they are just electrical discharge in space.

If a GRB emits rays that are angularly limited to 2 degrees of width, at 6,000 light years, the width of the ray at 5000 light years away is 6000 x tan(1°) or about 100 light years radius. That means that every planet within that distance of us if we are the cnter of a GRB ray, are toast. In our region of the galaxy there are 0.1 stars per cubic light year, so there are (4 x pi x 100^3) / 3 or a little more than 400,000 stars within 87 light years, and perhaps 140x that number in the path getting here, not to speak of how many more beyond are close enough (remember that we are 25,000 light years from the center of the Milky Way). This is a sobering fact. It is estimated that a GRB fires in a galaxy like the Milky Way once every 100,000 to a million years, as few as 4,500 since the sun started up, and perhaps 10x more On The Average.

This might be a stupid question, but could Earth have been effected by GRBs at some point in the distant future or past? I ask because I was under the impression that the Sun orbits the centre of the Milky Way in such a way the the relative position of other stars changes over long time-scales.

If so, GRBs might be behind some of Earths mass extinction events, particular the Ordovician-Silurian, Late Devonian or Triassic-Jurassic, the causes of which are still fairly mysterious. The conventional culprits are asteroids and volcanism (aided perhaps by continental drift) but GRBs and perhaps Supernova would also be sudden enough to do the job, although I don't know what their effects would be.

I was hoping between this or the supernova episode he'd get a bit more detailed on the types of supernovae. I mean, yeah, he's covered Types I & II along with electron capture supernovae and iron core collapse, but there's other types which are brilliantly fascinating, too, like photodisintegration or my favorite which is the pair instability supernova which leaves no remnant whatsoever. It's not the ultimate power in supernova types, but a special case of an iron core collapse where when the progenitor has just the right mass and metallicity, the outer core and middle of the star collapse in a way that actually tamps the energy output of the nuclear reactions occurring in the inner core causing the reactions to run away. The supernova behaves precisely the same as a 200 solar mass thermonuclear warhead, or hydrogen bomb. The detonation is so powerful that the star's gravity is no problem and the entire contents of the star is flung into space. Future episode?

Birth cries?  Not quite.  True they come about from black holes as they form, but a large black hole, perhaps a supermassive one, like those at the hearts of galaxies, consume matter so rapidly that they can (at the height of activity) produce beams of gamma radiation from the poles.  This is what quasars are, I think.  Black holes consuming matter at a phenomenal rate; enough to generate gamma rays.  They don't have to be supermassive, it's just that the matter consumption requirements for these phenomena are large enough that it is more likely to occur with much larger black holes.
